body:
Isn't the setting based on the user specified coreml flags, meaning a user would have to explicitly request this behavior?

`  options.usesCPUOnly = coreml_flags_ & COREML_FLAG_USE_CPU_ONLY;`

The ability to specify CPU only is primarily for validation. 
 
https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/5b65f1cb44eee6d82b9ba3b91a43b5b4a74ccae8/include/onnxruntime/core/providers/coreml/coreml_provider_factory.h#L15-L17

Spot on, @skottmckay. Humblest apologies - bit rusty on how bitwise OR on flags work I reckon. ðŸ˜Š 

Not sure if this the appropriate forum/ medium, but this insight unfortunately still doesn't solve my problem, i.e. not getting ANE to be utilised...
 
The models in question are those from the brilliant [Robust Video Matting (RVM)](https://github.com/PeterL1n/RobustVideoMatting) project. As far as I can see (refer below Netron output), they don't involve any subgraphs, so COREML_FLAG_ENABLE_ON_SUBGRAPH seemingly defaulting to being unflagged shouldn't matter.

What I specifically do is set up an InferenceSession through the Python API, explicitly passing the right provider, but no provider options. When I run an inference loop on random data for performance testing purposes per below, CoreMLExecutionProvider yields the exact same it/s figures as using CPUExecutionProvider, and I'm also not seeing load/ increased thermal activity on the ANE. Hence it's fairly obvious that the inference somehow defaults to CPU.

Any clues or other enlightenment will be massively appreciated!

 ```python
import onnxruntime as ort
import numpy as np
from tqdm import tqdm

sess = ort.InferenceSession('/Users/simon/Downloads/rvm_mobilenetv3_fp32.onnx', providers=['CoreMLExecutionProvider'])

rec = [ np.zeros([1, 1, 1, 1], dtype=np.float32) ] * 4
downsample_ratio = np.array([0.25], dtype=np.float32)

for _ in tqdm(range(1000)):
    src = np.float32(np.random.rand(1,3,1080,1920))
    fgr, pha, *rec = sess.run([], {
    'src': src, 
    'r1i': rec[0], 
    'r2i': rec[1], 
    'r3i': rec[2], 
    'r4i': rec[3], 
    'downsample_ratio': downsample_ratio
    })
```

![rvm_mobilenetv3_fp32 onnx](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13904873/137827191-bca058e9-9681-446c-a36e-f2c7c6d89bf1.png)

rename.to: CoreML provider (Python API): ANE/ GPU not used, falling back on CPU?

body:
CoreML doesn't support dynamic dimensions, so the 'batch_size' dimension in the ONNX model will cause it to fall back to CPU

https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/5da4e07daa02bbfea1edece08ba52a76cec13d13/onnxruntime/core/providers/coreml/builders/model_builder.cc#L132-L133

As an experiment you could try hacking the model to replace the batch_size dimension with the value 1. I tried the following and it seemed to run successfully.

```python
import onnx
from onnx import shape_inference

def update_dim_param(value_infos, dim_name='batch_size', dim_value=1):
    for vi in value_infos:
        if vi.type.HasField("tensor_type"):
            shape = vi.type.tensor_type.shape
            if shape:
                for dim in shape.dim:
                    if dim.HasField('dim_param') and dim.dim_param == dim_name:
                        dim.Clear()
                        dim.dim_value = dim_value

m = onnx.load(r'rvm_mobilenetv3_fp32.onnx')

update_dim_param(m.graph.input)
update_dim_param(m.graph.output)
update_dim_param(m.graph.value_info)

m1 = onnx.shape_inference.infer_shapes(m)
onnx.checker.check_model(m1)
onnx.save(m1, r'rvm_mobilenetv3_fp32.batch_size_1.onnx')
```

Here is the list of ONNX operators currently supported by CoreML execution provider, https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/execution-providers/CoreML-ExecutionProvider.html#supported-ops

If your model contains a lot of operators which are not supported by CoreML execution provider, the model execution will be heavily partitioned between CPU and CoreML execution providers, this may cause inferior performance due to the high cost of IO between different processors (CPU and ANE)

The onnx model on the Robust Video Matting (RVM) depot is exported from pytorch using dynamic axes, which contains many operators which will not be supported by CoreML, you may try to re-export the ONNX model using static axes, see
https://github.com/PeterL1n/RobustVideoMatting/blob/0feebf4af3a6d53e57871ffca74d0062587da227/export_onnx.py#L44-L73

Thank you both, @skottmckay and @gwang-msft!

No joy with the quick and dirty hack, so I ended up re-exporting the model without the dynamic axes. Now the trouble is - albeit I frankly don't fully understand the inner workings of RVM - it appears that the recurrent states _need_ to be dynamic. 

```
2021-10-19 18:36:28.075866 [W:onnxruntime:, helper.cc:61 IsInputSupported] Dynamic shape is not supported for now, for input:886
2021-10-19 18:36:28.075872 [W:onnxruntime:, helper.cc:61 IsInputSupported] Dynamic shape is not supported for now, for input:906
...
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/private/tmp/onnxruntime-20211018-19736-2bcn40/build/test.py", line 14, in <module>
    fgr, pha, *rec = sess.run([], {
  File "/private/tmp/onnxruntime-20211018-19736-2bcn40/build/onnxruntime/capi/onnxruntime_inference_collection.py", line 188, in run
    return self._sess.run(output_names, input_feed, run_options)
onnxruntime.capi.onnxruntime_pybind11_state.InvalidArgument: [ONNXRuntimeError] : 2 : INVALID_ARGUMENT : Got invalid dimensions for input: r4i for the following indices
 index: 1 Got: 64 Expected: 1
 index: 2 Got: 17 Expected: 1
 index: 3 Got: 30 Expected: 1
 Please fix either the inputs or the model.
```
Also, the limited set of supported operations would, to Guoyu's point around CPU-ANE partitioning, probably be a problem more generally.

So it's probably better for me to abandon the path of trying to use CoreML through ONNX Runtime and rather try a native Objective-C implementation on the basis of the [separate exporter](https://github.com/PeterL1n/RobustVideoMatting/tree/coreml).

Again, many thanks for your support!

Out of interest what didn't work with the quick-and-dirty hack? I was able to successfully execute a model updated that way.

The lack of support for at least HardSigmoid would make using CoreML very inefficient though.

I applied it to the original model and still ended up in the "Dynamic shape is not supported..." branch of the code. No in-depth analysis of the reasons done (for which hope you'll forgive me for that as I sincerely appreciate the effort you put into the hack!).

As you say, the absence of support for certain ops is the really pertinent point here as it determines the _practical_ feasibility of running these models in real time.
Your reference to HardSigmoid specifically relates to the onnxrt provider not currently supporting it, right? As opposed to the CoreML framework as such.

The InvalidArgument error is because your input doesn't match what the model claims to want. The r?? inputs and outputs say they should have the same shape as `src` (with the exception of `channels` which is hardcoded in `src` so in theory could differ). 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/979079/138005392-bbe16485-3f46-481b-a75d-8035c03a2641.png)

But you're passing zeros with shape {1,1,1,1}

```python
rec = [ np.zeros([1, 1, 1, 1], dtype=np.float32) ] * 4
```

If those inputs are provided with the same shape as `src` there's an error from an Expand node. 

> onnxruntime.capi.onnxruntime_pybind11_state.Fail: [ONNXRuntimeError] : 1 : FAIL : Non-zero status code returned while running Expand node. Name:'Expand_174' Status Message: Expand_174: right operand cannot broadcast on dim 3 LeftShape: {1,3,1080,1920}, RightShape: {1,64,17,30}

That's due to the model producing completely different shapes for the r?o values. Shapes produced:
```
(1, 16, 135, 240)
(1, 20, 68, 120)
(1, 40, 34, 60)
(1, 64, 17, 30)
```

After adjusting the input and output shapes to match those that I was able to run the model with fixed input sizes. However that won't help because of the Resize node (Resize_3) very early on that is taking a dynamic input for the `scales` value. Due to that, the ONNX shape inferencing can't infer the output shape (it doesn't know the values to use), and most things downstream of that end up with one or more dynamic dimensions. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/979079/138009033-b65226bd-7221-4826-a58a-05a464466278.png)

If the downsample_ratio was provided by a constant initializer it would be able to and we'd get to a point where it would come down to operators that the ORT CoreML EP doesn't support. 

>Your reference to HardSigmoid specifically relates to the onnxrt provider not currently supporting it, right? As opposed to the CoreML framework as such.
Yeah - we don't have that currently but could add it and assumably use [this]{https://apple.github.io/coremltools/mlmodel/Format/NeuralNetwork.html#activationsigmoidhard}

FWIW if the model had fixed input sizes, we could add support for Sub/Div/Mul/HardSigmoid to the ORT CoreML EP easily. Split/Slice/ReduceMean reasonable easily. Expand is not really needed. There's one Expand node per r?i input which converts the input to the actual shape required (which is why you can get away with passing in {1,1,1,1} for the initial state). If you provide those inputs with the correct shape those nodes aren't needed, but it's also fine for them to run on CPU as they're on the edge.

FWIW script to update the model so that the inputs/outputs have fixed sizes and the downsample_ratio is a constant value.

```python
import onnx
from onnx import shape_inference

r_shapes = [(1, 16, 135, 240),
            (1, 20, 68, 120),
            (1, 40, 34, 60),
            (1, 64, 17, 30)]

def update_model():
    m = onnx.load(r'rvm_mobilenetv3_fp32.onnx')

    def update_dim_values(value_infos, updates):
        for vi in value_infos:
            if vi.type.HasField("tensor_type"):
                shape = vi.type.tensor_type.shape
                if shape:
                    for dim in shape.dim:
                        if dim.HasField('dim_param') and dim.dim_param in updates:
                            dim_param = dim.dim_param  # save before Clear
                            dim.Clear()
                            dim.dim_value = updates[dim_param]

    def update_named_input_output(items, updates):
        for item in items:
            if item.name in updates:
                new_dims = updates[item.name]
                for idx in range(len(new_dims)):
                    item.type.tensor_type.shape.dim[idx].Clear()
                    item.type.tensor_type.shape.dim[idx].dim_value = new_dims[idx]

    def fix_downsample_ratio(graph):
        from onnx import helper
        from onnx import TensorProto
        if graph.input[len(graph.input) - 1].name == 'downsample_ratio':
            graph.input.pop()
            # add initializer instead
            ratio = helper.make_tensor('downsample_ratio', TensorProto.FLOAT, [1], [0.25])
            graph.initializer.append(ratio)

    input_updates = {
        'r1i': r_shapes[0],
        'r2i': r_shapes[1],
        'r3i': r_shapes[2],
        'r4i': r_shapes[3]
    }

    output_updates = {
        'r1o': r_shapes[0],
        'r2o': r_shapes[1],
        'r3o': r_shapes[2],
        'r4o': r_shapes[3]
    }

    updates = { 'batch_size': 1,
                'channels': 3,
                'height': 1080,
                'width': 1920 }

    update_named_input_output(m.graph.input, input_updates)
    update_named_input_output(m.graph.output, output_updates)

    update_dim_values(m.graph.input, updates)
    update_dim_values(m.graph.output, updates)
    update_dim_values(m.graph.value_info, updates)

    fix_downsample_ratio(m.graph)

    m1 = onnx.shape_inference.infer_shapes(m)
    onnx.checker.check_model(m1)
    onnx.save(m1, r'rvm_mobilenetv3_fp32.fixed.onnx')

update_model()

```

Apologies for the long radio silence, @skottmckay. It's the exact opposite of the absolutely outstanding responsiveness and ambition of this project - which couldn't be more appreciated!

So the downsample_ratio (per the authors' recommendation) is basically a linear function of input/ output resolution. Given _native_ CoreML would require those resolutions to be static, I don't see why we couldn't also make downsample_ratio a constant.

I frankly still don't understand the model well enough to tell whether the recurrent states' dimensions could also be set to the input/ output resolution directly, but neither do I see why not.

Which indeed  brings us to the scope of available operators. HardSigmoid in particular could more or less easily be replaced, however - I still haven't been able to gap-analyse this and may never find that time - others currently not in the mix may be needed without a feasible alternative.
Having said that in terms of my particular use case, I would _generally_ assume that with Apple Silicon being a bit of a rising star, you would want to support as many operators as quickly as possible anyhow? :)
Also - albeit I'm certainly not an expert and therefore probably wouldn't dare sending any amateur-quality PRs your way - adding additional individual operators on shouldn't be the biggest of deals in view of the CoreML support already in place as well as the Apple documentation you cite?

Anyway, will appreciate your thoughts, specifically as to whether there's merit in raising a dedicated Issue around additional CoreML operators.
